User Stories

# 

<span key="4a9ac07db214456c8f7d80ea228f81c7"><span offset-key="4a9ac07db214456c8f7d80ea228f81c7:0">User Stories</span></span>

## 

<span key="2421cef354cf4abeba0dbbe76977490b"><span offset-key="2421cef354cf4abeba0dbbe76977490b:0">What are User Stories?</span></span>

<span key="8bdbff542eab4827b0cd06f273714938"><span offset-key="8bdbff542eab4827b0cd06f273714938:0">A </span>**user story**<span offset-key="8bdbff542eab4827b0cd06f273714938:2"> is the smallest unit of work in an agile framework. It’s </span>**an end goal expressed from the user’s perspective**<span offset-key="8bdbff542eab4827b0cd06f273714938:4">.</span></span>

<span key="18130f4f2efd40459343c3e9c1f195d0"><span offset-key="18130f4f2efd40459343c3e9c1f195d0:0">The user story is an informal, general explanation of a software feature written from the perspective of the end-user or stakeholder. Note that it's not a feature itself!</span></span>

<span key="76aec51d85414688a40d29e60bbe2449"><span offset-key="76aec51d85414688a40d29e60bbe2449:0">The purpose of a user story is to articulate how a piece of work will deliver a particular value back to the stakeholder. Note that "stakeholders" don't have to be external end-users in the traditional sense. They can also be internal stakeholders or colleagues within your organization who depend on your team. A </span>**stakeholder**<span offset-key="76aec51d85414688a40d29e60bbe2449:2"> is anyone who has a stake in the development of a product.</span></span>

<span key="4be6fe94304e463cb7c062bb15307719"><span offset-key="4be6fe94304e463cb7c062bb15307719:0">User stories are a sentence or two in simple language that outline the desired outcome. They don't go into detail. Requirements are added later, once agreed upon by the team.</span></span>

## 

<span key="0e641953fcc141ffb17c68ae96e06bc2"><span offset-key="0e641953fcc141ffb17c68ae96e06bc2:0">User Story Formats</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="f1d23459d4f6443f89e02f69d94b6b14"><span offset-key="f1d23459d4f6443f89e02f69d94b6b14:0">As a (</span>**who**<span offset-key="f1d23459d4f6443f89e02f69d94b6b14:2"> wants to accomplish something)</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="c01c4838b0d649a8aef7831f359413b0"><span offset-key="c01c4838b0d649a8aef7831f359413b0:0">I want to (</span>**what**<span offset-key="c01c4838b0d649a8aef7831f359413b0:2"> they want to accomplish)</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="2f601227ad4d405f9e5d0d323fa50418"><span offset-key="2f601227ad4d405f9e5d0d323fa50418:0">So that (</span>**why/rationale**<span offset-key="2f601227ad4d405f9e5d0d323fa50418:2"> on what the user wants to accomplish)</span></span>

<span key="5ae410fad09842f7a4956d5f682efad4">**Example:**<span offset-key="5ae410fad09842f7a4956d5f682efad4:1"> As a </span>***user***<span offset-key="5ae410fad09842f7a4956d5f682efad4:3">, I want to </span>***log in using a username and password***<span offset-key="5ae410fad09842f7a4956d5f682efad4:5"> so that </span>***the system can authenticate my login.***</span>

## 

<span key="03a85680cc0d4d34864b4cd65131c8c5"><span offset-key="03a85680cc0d4d34864b4cd65131c8c5:0">User Stories and Agile Development</span></span>

<span key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967"><span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:0">Stories fit neatly into agile frameworks like Scrum and Kanban. </span>**Agile**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:2"> is a development methodology that focuses on </span>**responsiveness to change**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:4">—keeping the development process </span>**lean**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:6"> and focusing on keeping everybody </span>**aligned**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:8">. You keep development cycles short, so you can get a </span>**minimum viable product**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:10"> (MVP) up and running quickly, and then </span>**iterate**<span offset-key="1b8628186ff3444fbd1491633b312967:12"> (repeat) during the next cycle based on what you learn from it. In Labs, we'll use an agile workflow that you'll be able to translate into a wide variety of work environments in the industry.</span></span>

<span key="695e90938a7c4f9c95558cf2d8546d90"><span offset-key="695e90938a7c4f9c95558cf2d8546d90:0">In Agile, user stories are added to sprints and “burned down” throughout the sprint. </span>**Kanban**<span offset-key="695e90938a7c4f9c95558cf2d8546d90:2"> teams pull user stories into their backlog and run them through their workflow. </span>**Trello**<span offset-key="695e90938a7c4f9c95558cf2d8546d90:4"> is a form of Kanban to help your team manage their user stories and tasks. Thanks to stories, Kanban teams learn how to manage work-in-progress (WIP) and refine their workflows.</span></span>

<span key="70bd29c5d1e04c5dbc48968f7eacf00a"><span offset-key="70bd29c5d1e04c5dbc48968f7eacf00a:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="cdadb53a39754f08ac25b28441c4c847"><span offset-key="cdadb53a39754f08ac25b28441c4c847:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="ebdb8a7d74b247cf882aee9463a2cce7"><span offset-key="ebdb8a7d74b247cf882aee9463a2cce7:0">Trello</span></span>

## 

<span key="148afe59df06461f88cc202b44995d2b"><span offset-key="148afe59df06461f88cc202b44995d2b:0">Trello and Kanban</span></span>

<span key="c24a7ebc9d4940c699e32bfd86ee038b">**Kanban**<span offset-key="c24a7ebc9d4940c699e32bfd86ee038b:1"> is a methodology that comes from Japanese manufacturing practices developed in the mid-20th century. Factories would use written cards handed from person to person to communicate the status of operations. These cards were a "lean" way to manage the creation of products that was highly responsive to the realities on the ground.</span></span>

<span key="6f3c617ffa7f4f0984d80e19328725d6"><span offset-key="6f3c617ffa7f4f0984d80e19328725d6:0">In the same way as efficiently manufacturing cars, agile software development requires responsiveness to changing realities. Microsoft began developing an approach (that was soon iterated by many) to track progress on a "</span>**Kanban board**<span offset-key="6f3c617ffa7f4f0984d80e19328725d6:2">"—a set of columns containing cards representing bits of work. The development team would move the cards along the board to different columns to represent their status.</span></span>

<span key="2adac6da5072418796f887fb3829d9ec"><span offset-key="2adac6da5072418796f887fb3829d9ec:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://trello.com/home" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b5ec0b7a5b5f47de82a02b1bf670d968" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-20672_259-20673-237__"><span data-key="007d83933dab4762ac4d7c34a037a862"><strong>Trello (Links to an external site.)</strong></span></span></a><span key="dab1163e78954861a04ecb60ce80b4e1"> <span offset-key="dab1163e78954861a04ecb60ce80b4e1:1">is an implementation of a Kanban board system by the Australian software company </span></span><a href="https://www.atlassian.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7dadc32697444fbfbfe9b86c89e3eb70" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-20672_259-20673-237__"><span data-key="559eae3d3eb5408e81b12bf7b403d0e3"><span data-offset-key="559eae3d3eb5408e81b12bf7b403d0e3:0">Atlassian (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="8e0d4e70e2424abcb32d039c58cee38b"><span offset-key="8e0d4e70e2424abcb32d039c58cee38b:0">. Trello lets a software development team track the progress of bits of work throughout the SDLC.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f3018135b37d40a4b5d4e00b239e3232"><span offset-key="f3018135b37d40a4b5d4e00b239e3232:0">Trello in Labs</span></span>

<span key="a214ad67ebc942b7a5ddf14142c07a05"><span offset-key="a214ad67ebc942b7a5ddf14142c07a05:0">In Labs, you'll use Trello to track all the state of all development on your product.</span></span>

<span key="1b6423c1d17f49b3a3aaf1dafc979306"><span offset-key="1b6423c1d17f49b3a3aaf1dafc979306:0">Here's a high-level overview of how we'll use Trello in Labs:</span></span>

<span key="d9417c5f71bd4849bab1d99d4e34057a"><span offset-key="d9417c5f71bd4849bab1d99d4e34057a:0">And here's a look at the Trello </span>**workflow**<span offset-key="d9417c5f71bd4849bab1d99d4e34057a:2"> we'll use in Labs:</span></span>

<span key="1191047d930249b9b660546e4684371a"><span offset-key="1191047d930249b9b660546e4684371a:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="42a5131500df4d70b517695c69c3d9ae"><span offset-key="42a5131500df4d70b517695c69c3d9ae:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="b5309010987e4fbe8e31ddc338ae8274"><span offset-key="b5309010987e4fbe8e31ddc338ae8274:0">Tasks</span></span>

## 

<span key="5ddb06ce08f747c1a21f8ecc362d5b33"><span offset-key="5ddb06ce08f747c1a21f8ecc362d5b33:0">Tasks</span></span>

<span key="492f90aa5ff8470bb437a0159fd9f11e"><span offset-key="492f90aa5ff8470bb437a0159fd9f11e:0">A </span>**task**<span offset-key="492f90aa5ff8470bb437a0159fd9f11e:2"> is a granular unit of work that needs to get done to ship a user story.</span></span>

<span key="2e4f8223965e4a43897bc1fb62f73c19"><span offset-key="2e4f8223965e4a43897bc1fb62f73c19:0">One thing that needs to be established right away is the fact that </span>**this is a team effort**<span offset-key="2e4f8223965e4a43897bc1fb62f73c19:2">. While your team's Technical Project Managers are responsible for prioritizing the backlog and capturing requirements from the business and the users, the developers are really the ones best positioned to understand what in terms of technical capabilities must be developed, as well as the level of effort that will entail.</span></span>

## 

<span key="cbc3b8d76f234f5fb41559bf503f6130"><span offset-key="cbc3b8d76f234f5fb41559bf503f6130:0">Tips for Tasks</span></span>

<span key="b900d10f93074c7a8117bc19a06df4f6"><span offset-key="b900d10f93074c7a8117bc19a06df4f6:0">There are a few important things to consider when breaking down user stories into tasks:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="5116b78545c24c8d9ff3eb7d3b4a3d76">***Keep tasks small, but not too small*.**<span offset-key="5116b78545c24c8d9ff3eb7d3b4a3d76:2"> As a rule of thumb, a task should be something that can be done within a single day, but not in a few minutes' time either.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="784629a91bc34c67b25073a6e2d019b0">***Keep tasks very precise in scope*.**<span offset-key="784629a91bc34c67b25073a6e2d019b0:2"> Don't create tasks with such vague statements as "Coding" or "Implementation" thinking that anyone can just refer to the parent user story for details. Write something more meaningful that also makes the scope very clear. For example: "Develop the login class."</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="bef2bd74953549c5b352246b7d96c57d"><span offset-key="bef2bd74953549c5b352246b7d96c57d:0">Use the user story's </span>***acceptance criteria***<span offset-key="bef2bd74953549c5b352246b7d96c57d:2"> as a starting point, and its </span>***definition of done***<span offset-key="bef2bd74953549c5b352246b7d96c57d:4"> \*\*\*as a checklist. The acceptance criteria will help you determine what features need to be implemented, and the definition of done is a checklist for all user stories that can also help you determine if you're missing any tasks for the story to be </span>***done***<span offset-key="bef2bd74953549c5b352246b7d96c57d:6">.</span></span>

## 

<span key="8606712f427548fbb61eb59bcd63891a"><span offset-key="8606712f427548fbb61eb59bcd63891a:0">Breaking Down User Stories Into Tasks</span></span>

<span key="3783cd45efd74e729ac884a91b9e4de2"><span offset-key="3783cd45efd74e729ac884a91b9e4de2:0"> </span></span>

# 

<span key="e25d6be7fc4d49508ff5587b629b2ef0"><span offset-key="e25d6be7fc4d49508ff5587b629b2ef0:0">User Flows, Wireframes, and Styles</span></span>

## 

<span key="a5b4f76107da4d7283111d0e9db90bf0"><span offset-key="a5b4f76107da4d7283111d0e9db90bf0:0">User Flows and Wireframes</span></span>

<span key="d080d306c9e74acfb34132498bfe3ec3"><span offset-key="d080d306c9e74acfb34132498bfe3ec3:0">Designers frequently use lean artifacts like user flows and wireframes to think about and communicate how users will interact with anapplication.</span></span>

### 

<span key="e9f60f1ccc294a78b7d137cd564e90f8"><span offset-key="e9f60f1ccc294a78b7d137cd564e90f8:0">User Flows</span></span>

<span key="4f3eb1b9bcbb4baea7496113bf0a1cff"><span offset-key="4f3eb1b9bcbb4baea7496113bf0a1cff:0">A </span>**user flow**<span offset-key="4f3eb1b9bcbb4baea7496113bf0a1cff:2"> is a diagram that shows how a user moves through an application to achieve a goal.</span></span>

### 

<span key="1b2f3d8e9a00453984e15c53573c392d"><span offset-key="1b2f3d8e9a00453984e15c53573c392d:0">Wireframes</span></span>

<span key="bbff0657a08f48979ae7675f86f61f92"><span offset-key="bbff0657a08f48979ae7675f86f61f92:0">A </span>**wireframe**<span offset-key="bbff0657a08f48979ae7675f86f61f92:2"> is a basic blueprint of the layout, hierarchy, and components of a single screen or view.</span></span>

## 

<span key="6b4f5536c11f446db3efa766ffd625a4"><span offset-key="6b4f5536c11f446db3efa766ffd625a4:0">Styles</span></span>

<span key="b6fb91848c31405287a58b1a95df3c86">**Styles**<span offset-key="b6fb91848c31405287a58b1a95df3c86:1"> are anything that affects the feel or personality of an application. Styles can generally be boiled down to </span>**shape, color, and type**<span offset-key="b6fb91848c31405287a58b1a95df3c86:3">.</span></span>

<span key="1453bf06c27c49889c4c9ea67befb8d4"><span offset-key="1453bf06c27c49889c4c9ea67befb8d4:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="e056d3dac35a4a5f82c8a7054dceeb6a"><span offset-key="e056d3dac35a4a5f82c8a7054dceeb6a:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="26961f7ff7ac4b78b51af55a87faa966"><span offset-key="26961f7ff7ac4b78b51af55a87faa966:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<a href="introduction.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>

<a href="user-stories.html#tasks-1" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

<a href="user-stories.html#user-flows-wireframes-and-styles" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

User Flows, Wireframes, and Styles

<a href="user-stories.html#user-flows-and-wireframes" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

User Flows and Wireframes

<a href="user-stories.html#styles" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Styles
